pred:
**Youngest Person to Reach South Pole Solo: Scott Sears Completes 702-Mile Trek**

Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles, has become the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo, completing a 702-mile trek in just 38 days. Sears, brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, pulled a sled and supplies through 150mph winds and temperatures of -50c, reaching the pole on Christmas Day, 12 days ahead of schedule.

The journey was not without its challenges, with Sears describing hitting a wall on Christmas Eve, feeling like he couldn't take another step. However, after a brief rest, he was back on his way, fueled by juice, biltong, chocolate, and music on his iPod.

Sears' feat has raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust to help rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. He has also been praised by Andy Murray's mother, Judy, who tweeted congratulations on his achievement.

Sears' trek was not only a personal challenge but also a testament to his physical and mental endurance. He spent five weeks alone in a tent, facing extreme weather conditions and navigating crevasses and glaciers. Despite the challenges, Sears remains proud of his achievement, saying it will take a few weeks for everything to sink in.

Sears' journey has also sparked interest from the Guinness Book of Records, with the organization yet to confirm whether his feat will make it into the record books. Regardless, Sears' achievement is an impressive one, and he has earned widespread recognition for his bravery and determination.
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)

pred:
A convicted murderer, Michael David Elliot, 40, escaped from the Ionia Correctional Facility in Michigan on Sunday evening. He was serving five life sentences for four murders and an armed robbery that occurred in 1993. Elliot was last seen wearing a blue and orange state prison uniform, but was later spotted in black pants, a white t-shirt, white tennis shoes, and a white beanie cap.

After escaping, Elliot carjacked a woman using a box cutter and held her hostage during a 100-mile drive to Elkhart County. The woman escaped at a gas station by asking for a cup of water and locking herself in the bathroom. Elliot fled in the victim's car, a red Jeep Liberty, which was later found in Shipshewana, Indiana.

A manhunt was launched, and Elliot was eventually arrested in LaPorte County, Indiana, after a short chase. He was found to have stolen four vehicles during his 24-hour run from the law. Elliot is being held without bond on felony car theft and resisting charges.

The investigation into the escape is ongoing, and authorities are reviewing the incident to determine how Elliot was able to escape. Michigan Governor Rick Snyder has promised a thorough investigation and has expressed relief that Elliot was captured and is no longer a threat to the public.

Elliot's family has been notified, and authorities are urging anyone who comes into contact with him to contact law enforcement immediately. He is described as a 5'8", 165-pound white male with brown hair and eyes, and should be considered armed and dangerous.
answers: A convicted killer who escaped from a Michigan prison yesterday and carjacked a woman has been arrested after a car chase in rural LaPorte Country, Indiana, WNDU reports. Michael David Elliot, 40, allegedly stole a woman's red jeep and abandoned it in the small town of Shipshewana, Indiana, this afternoon. A woman spotted the car and called police, who said the vehicle had been seen in the area as early as 5:30am. Knowing Elliot "can go a lot of places in seven hours," police went door-to-door and had schools locked down before releasing students under a heavy police presence. Then a call about a stolen vehicle came in to the LaPorte County Sheriff's Office, and a deputy saw the vehicle and attempted a traffic stop, WOOD-TV reports. But the driver kept going and led authorities on a 5-minute chase. Stop sticks disabled his tires in Kankakee Township; Elliot jumped out and tried to run but was arrested and booked. He was serving five life sentences for the murders of four people when he broke out of the Ionia Correctional Facility yesterday by slipping through a gap in the fencing system.

pred:
**Dramatic Pursuit of Stolen Tractor Ends in Downtown Denver**

A stolen tractor towing an attachment was pursued by Denver Police Department (DPD) officers through central Denver on Friday night, resulting in a dramatic and chaotic chase. The tractor, which was stolen from a Denver Water facility, was driven through busy city streets and sidewalks, causing damage to several cars and buildings.

The pursuit began near City Park and ended near 15th and Market Streets in the Lower Downtown (LoDo) area, after a police cruiser rammed the tractor head-on, causing its airbags to deploy. The officer who drove the cruiser was forced to use a Taser to subdue the tractor driver.

Two DPD officers were taken to the hospital with injuries, but both were treated and released by Saturday morning. The suspect, a male, was apprehended and taken away in an ambulance. Police have not released his identity as the investigation is ongoing.

The pursuit was captured on video, showing the tractor weaving through traffic and pedestrians, with multiple police cars and a helicopter in pursuit. Witnesses described the scene as intense, with one saying the impact of the police cruiser hitting the tractor was strong enough to make the airbags deploy.

Despite the chaos, no shots were fired by police, and the suspect was taken into custody without further incident. The DPD is still investigating the circumstances of the chase and the identity of the suspect.
answers: Imagine looking outside and seeing over a dozen cop cars chasing ... a tractor. That was the scene in Denver last night when a stolen tractor towing an attachment smashed into cars and buildings as it plowed through downtown, the Huffington Post reports. Addie Hooper, 20, was visiting from Texas with family when she looked out a restaurant window onto Market Street and saw a police SUV crash into the tractor: "We were just like, 'Woah, that's crazy!" Hooper tells the Denver Post. Police vehicles rushed the scene and officers jumped out with guns drawn. "We thought they were going to shoot him," she adds. Instead, officers Tased the driver and made sure he was carted off by ambulance. Two officers sustained non-life-threatening injuries, and no reports have emerged of injured pedestrians. "It could've definitely been a lot worse," a witness tells KDVR. No more details have emerged, but police say the slow-speed chase began around City Park and concluded downtown, where officers rammed the tractor to protect pedestrians. Among Twitter videos, this one seems to capture it best. (Read about the easiest suspect chase ever.)

pred:
A Palestinian teenager, Muhammad Hussein Abu Khdeir, 16, was abducted and killed in Jerusalem, sparking widespread outrage and violence. The crime was reportedly carried out by Jewish extremists in revenge for the deaths of three kidnapped Jewish Israeli teens, whose bodies were found earlier in the week. The abduction and murder of Abu Khdeir brought strong condemnations from the Obama Administration and European officials, and threatened to escalate tensions between Israelis and Palestinians.

The incident occurred on Wednesday, when Abu Khdeir was forced into a car by two men on a sidewalk in the Shuafat neighborhood of East Jerusalem. His charred body was later found in a forest on the outskirts of the city. The Israeli police have launched an investigation into the murder, but the family of Abu Khdeir has accused the authorities of not doing enough to find the perpetrators.

The killing has sparked widespread protests and clashes between Palestinians and Israeli police, with dozens of people injured. The Palestinian Authority has condemned the murder and called for the perpetrators to be brought to justice. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has also condemned the murder and vowed to find those responsible.

The incident has also highlighted the deepening divide between Israelis and Palestinians, with many Palestinians refusing to accept the Israeli government's version of events and accusing it of perpetuating violence against Palestinians. The murder has also raised concerns about the rise of extremist groups in Israel and the potential for further violence.

In related news, Israel has begun reinforcing its forces on the border with Gaza, following a series of mortar and rocket attacks from Palestinian militants. The Israeli military has launched air strikes against targets in Gaza, and the Palestinian Authority has accused Israel of escalating the conflict.

The funeral of Abu Khdeir is expected to take place on Thursday, but it has been delayed due to a post-mortem examination. The family has accused the Israeli authorities of holding the body unnecessarily, and there are concerns that the funeral could be followed by further clashes between Palestinians and Israeli police.
answers: Mohammed Abu Khudair was heading to morning prayers at 4am yesterday when neighbors saw him forced into a van in east Jerusalem, his father says. They called his cell phone but "my son wasn't answering," his mother adds, per the BBC. An hour later, the Palestinian teen was found dead in an apparent revenge killing, so burned beyond recognition that DNA samples were needed to confirm his identify, father Hussein Abu Khudair tells NBC News, adding, per Time, "The settlers killed my son, they kidnapped him and killed him." More developments: The teen's funeral, originally set for today, has been delayed as authorities perform an autopsy, his father says. Khudair adds he doesn't have faith in the Israeli police "because we're Arab" and says young Jews pulled a 9-year-old boy away from his mother after Mohammed's death. Though he was saved, "he was scratched," Khudair says. "They grabbed him by his neck." Another relative of Mohammed adds "the hatred has increased" instantly in the family's neighborhood. "I've never seen such racism, even in the first and second intifada," he tells the New York Times. "We are entering a very dark time." Meanwhile, police are investigating what could be a third kidnapping after a girl called police from northern Israel. "She said that she was abducted and then the line went dead," an Israeli spokesman tells the Times. "We're searching the area. Helicopters are trying to track. We'll see what's going on there." In response to mortar and rocket attacks from Gaza, "the Israeli Air Force attacked 15 terror sites in Gaza early Thursday," an Israel Defense Forces official notes. "The targets included weapons manufacturing sites as well as training facilities." Some 10 Palestinians were reportedly injured.

pred:
**In Other Words Bookstore Cuts Ties with Portlandia**

The In Other Words bookstore in Portland, Oregon, has announced that it will no longer allow the TV show Portlandia to film at its location. The decision comes after a series of incidents, including a recent filming that left the store in disarray and staff mistreated. The bookstore's community also took issue with the show's portrayal of feminist issues, which they deemed trans-antagonistic and trans-misogynist. The show's depiction of trans women, particularly Black trans women, was criticized for being lazy, reactionary, and harmful.

The bookstore also expressed concerns about the show's lack of diversity, with no Black people appearing on the show and a small number of people of color. The production crew even asked the bookstore to remove a Black Lives Matter sign on its window during filming. The show's portrayal of gentrification in Portland was also seen as problematic, with the show's popularity being used to displace long-time residents and communities.

The current board, staff, and volunteers at In Other Words did not make the decision to allow Portlandia to film at the bookstore six years ago, but they stand behind the collective decision to discontinue the relationship. The bookstore is now seeking donations and volunteers to continue serving as a hub for Portland's social justice community.
answers: Portland's In Other Words bookstore is well known to Portlandia fans as the fictional Women and Women First bookstore featured in sketches on the show—but it's safe to say ties have been severed between the bookstore and the show, considering a sign that appears on the bookstore's door reading, "Fuck Portlandia! Transmisogyny – Racism – Gentrification – Queer Antagonism – Devaluation of Feminist Discourse." The Willamette Week tried on Tuesday to get an explanation from the bookstore, and a representative at first offered an interview, but also asked (repeatedly) for the Week to post a link to an online fundraiser the bookstore is running. After the Week declined to guarantee a link would be posted (though one did, in fact, end up getting posted in the ensuing article), the bookstore took back its offer of an interview in no uncertain terms. "After some consideration and research we've decided to officially tell the Willamette Weekly to go fuck themselves," read a message from the rep. "Your paper has absolutely zero journalistic professionalism and you are scummy rape apologists. Thanks for the opportunity tho! Have a great night." Then, Wednesday, a blog post went up on the bookstore's website explaining the "Fuck Portlandia" sign. It was placed on the window, and the store's relationship with the show was formally discontinued, as "a direct response to a particular egregious filming of the show in our space which saw our store left a mess, our staff mistreated, our neighbors forced to close and lose business for a day without warning, and our repeated attempts to obtain accountability or resolution dismissed," the blog post reads. "It was also a direct response to a show which is in every way diametrically opposed to our politics and the vision of society we’re organizing to realize. A show which has had a net negative effect on our neighborhood and the city of Portland as a whole." There's a lot more where that came from, here.

pred:
The California State Auditor's Office has released a report highlighting several instances of improper governmental activities and misconduct by state employees and agencies. The report includes seven examples of investigations that substantiated improper governmental activities, including misuse of state time, inaccurate attendance records, economically wasteful activities, and misuse of government property.

The report found that four employees at several agencies misused state time, resulting in a loss of approximately $160,000. Two employees at California State University, Fresno, engaged in egregious and continued time and attendance abuse, costing the state over $111,000. A nursing director at a Southern California adult prison removed a licensed vocational nurse from her assigned position to perform duties typically performed by an office technician, resulting in a waste of nearly $30,000.

The report also found that a California Department of Motor Vehicles employee slept at her desk for extended periods, misusing over 2,200 hours of work time and costing the state over $40,000. The employee's supervisors were aware of the issue but did not properly follow disciplinary procedures. The report also found that a high-ranking Cal Fire chief had an unauthorized structure built on state property, and two Fresno State University operations employees engaged in time and attendance abuse.

The report highlights the need for improved oversight and accountability in state government. The California State Auditor's Office has scheduled an August hearing to examine complaints of long DMV waits, and lawmakers are calling for increased transparency and accountability in state government.

Overall, the report highlights the importance of ensuring that state employees and agencies are held accountable for their actions and that improper governmental activities are addressed in a timely and effective manner.
answers: An employee responsible for logging changes in address and vehicle ownership at the California DMV slept at least three hours a day at her desk for nearly four years—and still has a job. The woman's 2,200 hours spent napping between February 2014 and December 2017 meant she completed less than half of her expected amount of work and cost the state more than $40,000, according to a worker misconduct report released Tuesday by the state's auditor. Per USA Today, the woman's doctor told the DMV that she was unable to perform her work duties, though a later doctor's note said the opposite. The employee continues to work for the state, per the Sacramento Bee.

pred:
Egypt is facing its worst crisis since President Mohamed Mursi took office six months ago. The crisis began when Mursi issued a decree giving himself wide powers and shielding his decisions from judicial review. The opposition, led by the National Salvation Front, has been protesting against the decree and the draft constitution written by an Islamist-led assembly.

On Wednesday, Islamist supporters of Mursi clashed with opposition protesters outside the presidential palace, with both sides throwing stones and petrol bombs. Riot police deployed to try to stop the confrontations, but were unable to halt the fighting. Medical sources reported that 23 people were wounded, including two Islamists who were hit in the legs by what their friends said were bullets fired during the clashes.

Vice President Mahmoud Mekky attempted to calm the crisis by proposing amendments to disputed articles in the constitution, which could be agreed with the opposition. A written agreement could then be submitted to the next parliament, to be elected after a referendum on the constitution on December 15.

The United States has called for dialogue on the constitution, which should "respect the rights of all citizens." Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said that Egypt's stability is a concern for the US, and that the country's authorities must make progress on the transition in an "inclusive manner."

The opposition has accused Mursi of creating a new autocracy and has called for him to retract the decree and defer the referendum. Mursi has shown no sign of buckling under pressure, and has said that his decree was needed to prevent courts still full of judges appointed by ousted strongman Hosni Mubarak from derailing a constitution vital for Egypt's political transition.

The crisis has spread to other cities, with offices of the Muslim Brotherhood's political party in Ismailia and Suez being torched. Prime Minister Hisham Kandil has called for calm, saying that the government is working to start a national dialogue.

The army, which has traditionally been the muscle behind all previous Egyptian presidents, has gone back to barracks, having apparently lost its appetite to intervene in politics. State institutions, with the partial exception of the judiciary, have mostly fallen in behind Mursi.

The crisis has also had an impact on the economy, with investors seizing on hopes that Egypt's turbulent transition may soon head for calmer waters. The government has turned to the IMF for a $4.8 billion loan after the depletion of its foreign currency reserves.
answers: Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi returned to the presidential palace today after fleeing yesterday when it was thronged by protesters, Reuters reports. Though 200 demonstrators camped out overnight, traffic was back to normal today and riot police had left the area. In yesterday's clashes, 35 protesters and 40 police officers were hurt. And things are looking to heat up again soon: The Muslim Brotherhood has called for a protest at the palace today against the "oppressive abuses" of the opposition, and the opposition in response called for leftist demonstrators to head back to the palace, leading to fears of violent clashes. Opposition protesters want Morsi to retract his expanded powers and stop a Dec. 15 vote on the new constitution hastily drafted by Islamists. Though they called yesterday's protest a "last warning" to the president, Reuters notes that they have little real chance of stopping the vote, which Morsi is confident will approve the constitution.

pred:
**Jamaican Bobsled Team Makes Catchy Comeback at 2014 Winter Olympics**

The Jamaican bobsled team is making a triumphant return to the Winter Olympics after a 12-year absence. The team, piloted by Winston Watts, will compete in the men's two-man bobsled event on February 16. To get fans pumped up, the Jamaican Tourist Board has released a catchy reggae tune called "The Bobsled Song," which syncs perfectly with the Olympic bobsled track's twists and turns.

The song, written by Sidney Mills and Jon Notar, features a bright 8-bit music video that tracks the team's progress on a map of the Sochi bobsled course. Fans can download the song and play it at the exact moment the Jamaican bobsled team begins their run, creating an amazing theme song that reflects the team's progress throughout the race.

The Jamaican team, which qualified for the competition for the first time since 2002, is considered a long shot to win a medal. However, their participation in the Olympics is a significant milestone, especially given their absence from the Winter Games since 2002. The team's run to the Calgary Games in 1988 was famously depicted in the film "Cool Runnings."

Fans can follow the Jamaican bobsled team's progress on Twitter @JAMBOBSLED and watch their training sessions on the Associated Press website. The team's first heat starts on February 16 at 11:15AM EST.
answers: Jamaica's incredible bobsledding run to the Winter Olympics now has a theme song to go with it—named, appropriately, "The Bobsled Song," the AP reports. The upbeat tune by Sidney Mills and Jon Notard plays perfectly in sync with the team's 4,921-foot run in Sochi and wraps up with "Last turn, keep your head down/I see the finish line/Jamaica rock the whole town," reports Mashable. (See the 8-bit video here.) Considered a long shot to win a medal, the two-man team of Marvin Dixon and Winston Watts are aiming to recapture the thrill of the 1988 film Cool Runnings and ride the crowd-funding high that paid for country's first bobsledding Olympic appearance since 2002.

pred:
Two former Nazi SS guards in their 90s have been indicted in Germany on charges of being accessories to murder while they worked at the Stutthof concentration camp during World War II. The men, aged 93 and 92, served as guards at the camp in Poland and are accused of being aware of the killings that took place there, including the deaths of 65,000 people. The charges were filed under new German legal guidance that allows the prosecution of former Nazis who cannot be tied to specific killings.

The indictment was made possible by the testimony of Holocaust survivor Judith Meisel, 88, who identified one of the guards, Johann Rehbogen, as a teenage SS officer who taunted her and other female prisoners at the camp. Meisel, who was a prisoner at Stutthof, has been working with German prosecutors to bring the guards to justice and has described the experience of being in the camp in vivid detail.

The two men have denied any knowledge of the killings at the camp, but prosecutors believe that they were aware of the atrocities that took place there. The trial is expected to commence next summer if the defendants are deemed healthy enough to stand trial. Meisel has expressed her desire to participate in the trial as a witness or observer, and her son has said that she is still unsure how she will respond to the charges.

The indictment is seen as a significant step towards justice for the survivors of the Holocaust and their families. Meisel has said that she welcomes any chance to tell her story "for the important lessons it teaches about tolerance and racism." The case is also a reminder of the importance of holding individuals accountable for their actions, even if they are many years after the fact.
answers: Judith Meisel says that when she was a teenager in the Stutthof concentration camp in western Poland, other prisoners told her: "Don't let us die without you mentioning what happened to us." The 88-year-old Minnesota resident has not forgotten: Her testimony helped German authorities indict two former guards from the camp where 65,000 people, including Meisel's mother, died, the Minneapolis Star Tribune reports. She identified one former guard, 94-year-old Johann Rehbogen, as the young SS officer who would taunt female prisoners as they undressed. Prosecutors say the men can't be tied to specific murders, but their work as guards made the killings possible. Meisel—who escaped along with her sister when inmates were sent on a "death march" away from the camp in 1945—says she is willing to relive her horrific experiences to help prosecutors. "This process of seeking answers and finding justice for my mother gives new meaning to my life," she says. The two former guards have been charged as accessories to murder, the AP reports. They deny any knowledge of killings at the camp, where thousands were starved to death or froze. Prosecutors say prisoners were also gassed to death, shot, and killed with lethal injections. Authorities say Meisel and several other Stutthof survivors in the US could be called as witnesses if the former guards are deemed healthy enough to stand trial. (A pendant found at the Sobibor camp helped reunite a family.)

pred:
Here is a one-page summary of the news:

Actress Heather Lind has accused former President George H.W. Bush of sexually assaulting her during a photo opportunity in 2014. Lind, who starred in the TV series "Turn: Washington's Spies," claimed that Bush touched her from behind and told her a dirty joke while being photographed with his wife Barbara Bush. Bush has apologized for the incident, saying it was an "attempt at humor" and that he didn't mean to offend Lind.

However, another actress, Jordana Grolnick, has come forward with similar allegations. Grolnick claims that Bush touched her inappropriately during a photo opportunity in 2016, saying that he reached around to her behind and asked her if she wanted to know who his favorite magician was.

Bush's spokesperson has released a statement saying that the former president's arm falls on the lower waist of people with whom he takes pictures due to his age and confinement to a wheelchair. The spokesperson also claimed that Bush's actions were intended to be a good-natured manner, but some have seen it as inappropriate.

Lind's colleagues have come forward to support her allegations, including her co-star Kevin McNally and the author of the book on which "Turn" is based. The official "Turn" account also tweeted about the importance of addressing sexual assault and the abuse of power.

The allegations against Bush come in the wake of the Weinstein scandal and the fallout of many film and TV executives due to sexual harassment allegations. Lind's Instagram post, which included her allegations, has been deleted, but her message of empowerment and support for other women who have spoken out about their experiences has resonated with many.
answers: Actress Heather Lind accused former President George HW Bush of sexual assault in a now-deleted Instagram post Tuesday, saying the former president "touched her from behind" during a photo-op in 2014. The Turn: Washington's Spies star said the inappropriate behavior occurred during a special screening before the AMC historical drama's debut, Deadline reports. "He touched me from behind from his wheelchair with his wife Barbara Bush by his side," Lind wrote. "He told me a dirty joke. And then, all the while being photographed, touched me again. Barbara rolled her eyes as if to say 'not again.'" Lind said a security guard told her she "shouldn't have stood next to him for the photo." Lind said that judging from comments from people around her, Bush had behaved the same way with "countless other women." "My fellow castmates and producers helped me that day and continue to support me," she wrote. Lind said she decided to come forward with her story after seeing a recent photo of the 93-year-old Bush with former President Obama. Bush issued an apology through a spokesman. "President Bush would never—under any circumstance—intentionally cause anyone distress, and he most sincerely apologizes if his attempt at humor offended Ms. Lind," the spokesman said in a statement to the New York Daily News.
